comments:
In my application, I have the following function:

uint32_t PilotMain(uint16_t cmd, MemPtr cmdPBP, uint16_t launchFlags)
{
	// OS6NEW: New error type
	status_t error = errNone;
	...
}

When debugging my application, I can bring up a Disassembly view that displays:

{
0x4e6e13e9 <PilotMain>:     push   %ebp
0x4e6e13ea <PilotMain+1>:   mov    %esp,%ebp
0x4e6e13ec <PilotMain+3>:   sub    $0x18,%esp
0x4e6e13ef <PilotMain+6>:   mov    0x8(%ebp),%eax
0x4e6e13f2 <PilotMain+9>:   mov    0x10(%ebp),%edx
0x4e6e13f5 <PilotMain+12>:  mov    %ax,0xfffffffe(%ebp)
0x4e6e13f9 <PilotMain+16>:  mov    %dx,0xfffffffc(%ebp)
	// OS6NEW: New error type
	status_t error = errNone;
0x4e6e13fd <PilotMain+20>:  movl   $0x0,0xfffffff8(%ebp)
...

I find that double-clicking on text in the line with the C++ comment brings up 
a dialog that says: An error has occurred. See error log for more details.

The error log says: Problems occurred when invoking code from plug-
in: "org.eclipse.core.runtime".

The Exception Stack Trace at this point shows:

Putting a breakpoint on DisassemblyEditorInput.java:169 shows 
that "instructions" can be a zero-length array, so that "instructions[0]" 
causes an exception.
